quick_answer.what: Gamalama is an active stratovolcano that forms the entire island of Ternate off the western coast of Halmahera in North Maluku, Indonesia, rising to 1,714 m (5,623 ft) above sea level.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted October 2018. One of Indonesia's most frequently erupting volcanoes, with 84 recorded eruptions since 1510.
quick_answer.famous_for: The volcano on which the historic Sultanate of Ternate was built — the epicenter of the global spice trade (cloves) for centuries. Its near-perfect conical shape and extensive eruption record make it one of Indonesia's most iconic island volcanoes.
quick_answer.danger_level: High — the city of Ternate (population ~220,000) is built directly on the volcano's flanks, with no escape route except by sea. One of the most densely populated volcanic islands in Indonesia.

overview.content: Gamalama is an active stratovolcano that constitutes the entire island of Ternate in North Maluku province, Indonesia, located off the western coast of Halmahera in the Molucca Sea. With 84 recorded eruptions since 1510 — one of the longest documented eruption records of any Indonesian volcano — Gamalama is among the most frequently active volcanoes in Indonesia and in the entire Ring of Fire. The volcano's near-conical shape rises to 1,714 m (5,623 ft) above sea level, with three summit craters of progressively younger age extending northward. Gamalama's extraordinary eruption record owes much to its unique historical position: Ternate was the epicenter of the global clove trade from the 15th to 18th centuries, attracting Portuguese, Spanish, and Dutch colonial powers whose meticulous records documented volcanic activity with unusual detail for the era. Today, approximately 220,000 people live in the city of Ternate, built directly on the volcano's lower flanks, making Gamalama one of Indonesia's most densely populated volcanic islands. Unlike many volcanic islands where populations concentrate on one side, Ternate's settlements encircle the entire base of the cone, and evacuation in a major eruption would require transport by sea — a significant logistical challenge. Gamalama's eruptions are typically moderate (VEI 1–3) and summit-focused, though flank eruptions occurred in 1763, 1770, 1775, and 1962–63. The volcano sits on the western arm of the Halmahera arc, a volcanic chain generated by the complex double subduction of the Molucca Sea Plate. With 84 eruptions, Gamalama's eruption count rivals those of Etna and Stromboli, placing it among the most prolific volcanoes on the planet.

geology_and_formation.content: Gamalama sits on the Halmahera volcanic arc, one of the most tectonically complex regions on Earth. The Molucca Sea Plate is being subducted from both sides — westward beneath the Sangihe arc and eastward beneath the Halmahera arc — creating a unique double subduction zone that is one of only a few active examples worldwide. Gamalama's magma is generated by the eastward subduction of the Molucca Sea Plate beneath the Halmahera arc, producing andesitic to basaltic andesitic lavas typical of arc volcanism over thin oceanic crust less than 15 km thick. The volcano itself is a composite stratovolcano built from alternating layers of lava flows, pyroclastic deposits, and volcaniclastic sediments. Three summit cones, progressively younger to the north, define the modern summit structure. The southern cone is the oldest and most eroded, the central cone is moderately preserved, and the northern cone hosts the currently active summit craters. Several maars and secondary vents define a rift zone that cuts the volcano parallel to the Halmahera island arc. The most notable is the Ngade maar on the southern flank, formed approximately 14,500–13,000 years ago based on calibrated radiocarbon dating. The island of Ternate is approximately 10 km in diameter, and the volcano's flanks descend steeply into the Molucca Sea, suggesting that the subaerial portion represents only the upper fraction of a much larger submarine edifice that may rise 2,000–3,000 m from the seafloor.

eruption_history_overview.content: Gamalama possesses one of the longest and most detailed eruption histories of any volcano in Southeast Asia, with 84 eruptions documented since 1510 (67 confirmed, 17 uncertain). This remarkable record is a direct consequence of the European colonial presence on Ternate: Portuguese traders arrived in 1512, just two years after the first recorded eruption, and the subsequent Portuguese, Spanish, and Dutch colonial administrations maintained detailed records that captured volcanic events with unusual fidelity. The eruption frequency has been remarkably consistent: approximately 3 eruptions per decade from the 16th century onward, with the 19th century being the most active period (25 eruptions). The vast majority of eruptions have been small to moderate (VEI 1–2), with 11 reaching VEI 3 — the highest recorded level. No VEI 4 or larger eruption has been documented in the historical record, suggesting that Gamalama's eruption style is characteristically moderate, with frequent small explosive events rather than rare catastrophic ones. Eruptions have typically originated from the summit craters, though notable flank eruptions occurred in 1763 (north flank), 1770, 1775 (summit and northwest flank, 100 m from summit), and 1962–63 (east flank).

subsections.title: The 1510 and 1538 Eruptions — Early Colonial Records (VEI 3)
subsections.content: The first documented eruption of Gamalama occurred in 1510, just before Portuguese contact. The 1538 eruption was one of the first volcanic events in the Moluccas to be recorded by European observers. Both reached VEI 3, producing significant explosive activity that was noted in early colonial correspondence. These eruptions framed the earliest European understanding of volcanism in the East Indies and established Ternate's reputation as a volcanic hazard zone even as it attracted traders seeking its precious cloves.

subsections.title: The 1770s Eruption Cluster — Ternate's Most Active Decade (VEI 3)
subsections.content: Between 1770 and 1775, Gamalama erupted at least four times, including three VEI 3 events — the most intense clustering of significant eruptions in its historical record. The July 1770 eruption produced substantial explosive activity from the summit. The August 1771–1772 eruption continued for months. The 1775 eruption was particularly notable as it involved both the summit crater and a flank vent on the northwest side, just 100 m from the summit, producing lava flows and explosive activity. Dutch colonial records from this period describe ashfall disrupting the clove harvest, tremors damaging the Sultan's palace, and residents of Ternate city living in constant anxiety. This decade of hyperactivity demonstrated that Gamalama can sustain closely spaced eruptions that escalate in intensity.

subsections.title: The 1840 Eruption (VEI 3)
subsections.content: The eruption beginning February 2, 1840 was one of the more significant 19th-century events, producing substantial explosive activity from the summit crater. Dutch colonial observers documented heavy ashfall over Ternate and surrounding waters, disruption to shipping in the Molucca Sea, and evacuation of some settlements on the upper slopes. The 1840s were part of a remarkably active period for Gamalama — the volcano erupted in 1838, 1839, 1840, 1841, 1842, 1843, 1844, 1845, 1846, 1847, and 1849 — an extraordinary run of 11 eruptions in 12 years that stands as the most intense sustained period of activity in Gamalama's record.

subsections.title: The 1962–1963 Eruption — Flank Event (VEI 2)
subsections.content: Beginning on December 31, 1962 and continuing into 1963, this eruption was notable for originating on the east flank of the volcano rather than the summit. Flank eruptions at Gamalama are uncommon — only four have been documented in the historical record (1763, 1770, 1775, and 1962–63) — and they pose a particular hazard because lava and pyroclastic material are directed toward inhabited coastal areas rather than remaining near the summit. The 1962–63 eruption served as a reminder that Gamalama's hazard zone extends beyond the summit region.

subsections.title: The 1983 and 1990 Eruptions — Modern VEI 3 Events
subsections.content: The most significant eruptions in recent decades occurred on August 9, 1983 and April 25, 1990, both reaching VEI 3. The 1983 eruption produced an explosive column and ashfall that affected the expanding city of Ternate, which by then had grown significantly compared to colonial times. The 1990 eruption generated similar explosive activity and triggered evacuations in the upper city. These events demonstrated to modern authorities that Gamalama's eruptive potential had not diminished, and they prompted improvements in monitoring and emergency planning. Both eruptions were relatively brief but intense, consistent with Gamalama's pattern of short, sharp explosive events.

subsections.title: Recent Activity: 2011–2018
subsections.content: Gamalama has continued its pattern of frequent small eruptions into the 21st century. The December 5, 2011 eruption (VEI 2) produced an ash column and minor pyroclastic flows from the summit crater. On September 15, 2012, a VEI 1 eruption occurred. In December 2014 and July 2015, VEI 2 eruptions from the summit crater generated ash plumes and triggered localized evacuations. A VEI 1 eruption in August 2016 and the most recent eruption on October 4, 2018 (VEI 1) continued the pattern. These eruptions, while relatively small, demonstrate that Gamalama remains in a persistently active state and that the 220,000 residents of Ternate live with ongoing volcanic risk.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Gamalama is monitored by Indonesia's Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation (CVGHM, known locally as PVMBG), which operates seismic monitoring stations, visual observation posts, and deformation monitoring equipment on and around the volcano. The volcano's alert level has fluctuated in recent years, typically between Level I (Normal) and Level II (Advisory), with occasional elevation to Level III during periods of increased seismicity or eruption. The most recent eruption occurred on October 4, 2018, and since then Gamalama has continued to produce volcanic earthquakes, periodic increased fumarolic activity at the summit, and occasional SO₂ emissions above background levels. Given Gamalama's eruption frequency — averaging roughly one eruption every 6 years over its 500-year record — scientists consider further eruptions essentially certain. PVMBG maintains exclusion zones around the summit crater during elevated alert periods and coordinates with local disaster management authorities (BPBD) on evacuation planning for the city of Ternate.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Gamalama's hazard profile is dominated by the extreme exposure of its population. The city of Ternate, with approximately 220,000 inhabitants, encircles the base of the volcano, and the island's only airstrip and main port are on the coastal lowlands. In a major eruption, evacuation would require transport by sea to neighboring Halmahera or Tidore — a logistical challenge of enormous proportions. Gamalama's eruptions typically produce explosive columns, ashfall, ballistic projectiles near the summit, and occasional pyroclastic density currents. While the volcano has not produced an eruption larger than VEI 3 in its recorded history, the absence of very large eruptions in 500 years does not preclude future VEI 4+ events — Gamalama's geological record prior to 1510 is essentially unknown. Ashfall from even moderate eruptions affects the entire island, contaminating water supplies, damaging crops, and disrupting transportation. Lahars (volcanic mudflows) are a significant hazard during heavy rainfall following ashfall, as volcanic debris is remobilized down the steep slopes into populated areas. The summit area is particularly hazardous due to ballistic projectiles — rocks ejected at high velocity — which can reach distances of 1–3 km from the crater during explosive eruptions. The concentration of population, critical infrastructure, and limited evacuation routes makes Gamalama one of the highest-risk volcanic settings in Indonesia.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Ternate Island is approximately 10 km (6 mi) in diameter and is entirely composed of the Gamalama volcanic edifice. The near-conical shape of the volcano is one of the most visually striking in Indonesia, rising from sea level to 1,714 m (5,623 ft) in a steep, symmetrical profile visible from across the Molucca Sea. Three summit cones, aligned roughly north–south and progressively younger to the north, give the summit ridge a slightly elongated profile. The currently active northern crater complex is approximately 200 m in diameter. The flanks are deeply incised by radial drainage channels (barangos) that carry rainwater and, during eruptions, lahars toward the coast. The lower slopes are densely vegetated with tropical forest, clove plantations, and agricultural land, transitioning to sparse vegetation and volcanic debris above approximately 1,200 m. The city of Ternate occupies the eastern and southeastern coastal lowlands, with the historic Sultan's Palace (Kedaton) located on the eastern flank. The Ngade maar, a prominent volcanic crater lake approximately 500 m in diameter on the southern flank, is a popular local recreation site. Tidore Island, another volcanic island and the site of the rival Sultanate of Tidore, rises prominently just 2 km to the south across a narrow strait.

climate_and_global_impact.content: Gamalama's eruptions have been exclusively regional in their atmospheric impact. With a maximum historical VEI of 3, none of its documented eruptions have been large enough to inject significant quantities of aerosol into the stratosphere or produce measurable global climate effects. The volcano's equatorial location (0.81°N) means that any future larger eruption could potentially distribute aerosols across both hemispheres, though this remains hypothetical based on the known record. Locally, Gamalama's eruptions affect regional air quality through ash and SO₂ emissions, and heavy ashfall events can disrupt air traffic across the Molucca Sea region. The broader Halmahera volcanic arc, of which Gamalama is a part, includes several larger volcanoes that have historically produced more significant atmospheric effects.

cultural_significance.content: Gamalama occupies an extraordinary position in world history as the volcano beneath one of the most strategically important islands of the Age of Exploration. Ternate was the world's primary source of cloves for centuries, and control of this tiny volcanic island was contested by the Portuguese (who arrived in 1512), the Spanish, and the Dutch, who ultimately dominated the spice trade. The Sultanate of Ternate, one of the oldest Islamic sultanates in Southeast Asia (established ~1257), was built at the foot of Gamalama, and the Sultan's Palace (Kedaton) remains a cultural landmark. The volcano's eruptions were recorded in detail by colonial administrators, merchants, and missionaries, giving Gamalama one of the most extensive pre-modern eruption records in Asia. In local Ternatan culture, Gamalama is considered the spiritual center of the island, and traditional beliefs associate the volcano with powerful supernatural forces. The annual Festival Legu Gam, held in Ternate, celebrates the cultural heritage of the sultanate amid the backdrop of the volcano. Alfred Russel Wallace, the great Victorian naturalist, visited Ternate in 1858 and famously formulated the theory of natural selection while staying on the island — making Gamalama the volcanic backdrop to one of the most important moments in the history of science.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Gamalama is accessible from Ternate city, which serves as the capital of North Maluku province and has domestic flight connections from Manado, Makassar, and Jakarta via Sultan Babullah Airport. The summit hike is a popular, if challenging, day trek: the route typically starts from the village of Marikurubu or Tabala on the eastern flank and takes approximately 3–5 hours to ascend the 1,714 m peak. The trail passes through clove and nutmeg plantations, tropical forest, and increasingly barren volcanic terrain before reaching the crater rim, which offers panoramic views of the Molucca Sea, Halmahera, and the neighboring volcanic islands of Tidore, Maitara, and Makian. Hikers should be aware that summit access may be restricted during elevated alert levels. The Ngade maar on the southern flank is an accessible volcanic feature with a crater lake popular for swimming. In Ternate city, the restored Kedaton (Sultan's Palace), the Portuguese-era Fort Oranje, and the Benteng Tolukko offer insights into the island's rich spice trade history. Local guides are recommended for the summit trek and are available through guesthouses and tour operators in Ternate.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Gamalama is part of the Halmahera volcanic arc, a chain of active volcanoes in eastern Indonesia. Dukono, located 180 km to the north on northern Halmahera, has been in near-continuous eruption since 1933 and is one of the most persistently active volcanoes in Indonesia. Tidore Peak (1,730 m), on the neighboring island of Tidore just 2 km to the south, is a dormant volcanic edifice of similar stature. Makian, a highly active stratovolcano 60 km to the south, produced a devastating VEI 4 eruption in 1988 that forced the permanent evacuation of the island's population. The Halmahera arc also includes Gamkonora (1,635 m), which has produced VEI 3 eruptions and is one of the tallest volcanoes in the region. Together, these volcanoes form one of the most active and least-studied volcanic arcs in the Ring of Fire.

etymology.content: The name 'Gamalama' is of local Ternatan origin and has been the traditional name for the volcanic peak since before European contact. In some colonial-era sources, the volcano is referred to simply as 'Ternate Peak' or 'the mountain of Ternate.' The name is closely associated with the identity of the island and its people, and is used consistently in both local and scientific literature.

facts: Gamalama's 84 recorded eruptions since 1510 give it one of the longest and most complete eruption histories of any volcano in Southeast Asia, thanks to over 500 years of colonial and post-colonial documentation.
The entire island of Ternate — approximately 10 km in diameter — is composed of the single Gamalama stratovolcano, with approximately 220,000 people living on its flanks.
Ternate was the world's primary source of cloves for centuries, and European wars were fought over this tiny volcanic island, making Gamalama the geological foundation of the global spice trade.

Alfred Russel Wallace formulated his theory of natural selection in 1858 while staying on Ternate, making Gamalama the volcanic backdrop to one of the most important moments in the history of biology.
Between 1838 and 1849, Gamalama erupted 11 times in 12 years — the most intense sustained period of activity in its 500-year record.

Gamalama sits on a rare double subduction zone where the Molucca Sea Plate is being consumed from both sides simultaneously — one of only a few active examples of such a tectonic configuration on Earth.
The Ngade maar on Gamalama's southern flank formed approximately 14,500–13,000 years ago and now contains a popular crater lake used for recreation by Ternate residents.

In a major eruption, the entire population of Ternate (~220,000) would need to be evacuated by sea — there is no land route off the island — presenting one of the most challenging volcanic evacuation scenarios in Indonesia.
Three progressively younger summit cones, aligned north to south, give Gamalama an unusual triple-peaked summit profile visible from the Molucca Sea.
Only four flank eruptions have been recorded in Gamalama's history (1763, 1770, 1775, and 1962–63) — the vast majority of its 84 eruptions have originated from the summit craters.
The 19th century was Gamalama's most active period, with 25 eruptions — averaging one every 4 years throughout the century.
Gamalama's eruption record has never exceeded VEI 3, suggesting a characteristically moderate eruption style — but the pre-1510 geological record remains largely unstudied.

faqs.question: Is Gamalama Volcano still active?
faqs.answer: Yes, Gamalama is one of Indonesia's most active volcanoes. It has produced 84 recorded eruptions since 1510, most recently in October 2018. The volcano is continuously monitored by Indonesia's PVMBG (Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation), which maintains seismic and visual observation stations on and around the volcano. Gamalama's eruption frequency — averaging approximately one eruption every 6 years over its 500-year record — means that further eruptions are considered essentially certain. The volcano continues to produce volcanic earthquakes and periodic increased fumarolic activity, and alert levels are adjusted as conditions change.

faqs.question: When did Gamalama last erupt?
faqs.answer: Gamalama's most recent eruption occurred on October 4, 2018, classified at VEI 1, with an ash eruption from the summit crater. Prior to that, eruptions occurred in August 2016 (VEI 1), July 2015 (VEI 2), December 2014 (VEI 2), September 2012 (VEI 1), and December 2011 (VEI 2). This pattern of frequent small eruptions is characteristic of Gamalama, which has averaged roughly one eruption every 6 years over its 500-year historical record. The most significant recent eruptions were the VEI 3 events in 1983 and 1990.

faqs.question: How many people live on Gamalama?
faqs.answer: Approximately 220,000 people live in the city of Ternate and surrounding settlements on Gamalama's flanks. The city encircles the base of the volcano, with residential areas, government buildings, a university, the main commercial district, the airport, and the port all situated on the lower slopes and coastal lowlands. This makes Gamalama one of the most densely populated volcanic islands in Indonesia and one of the highest-risk volcanic settings in the world. Evacuation in a major eruption would require transport by sea to neighboring islands — a massive logistical undertaking.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Gamalama?
faqs.answer: Gamalama is classified as a stratovolcano (composite volcano), built from alternating layers of lava flows and pyroclastic (explosive) deposits. It has a near-conical shape that forms the entire island of Ternate, approximately 10 km in diameter. The summit features three cones of progressively younger age aligned north to south, with the northernmost cone hosting the currently active craters. Gamalama produces andesitic to basaltic andesitic magma typical of subduction zone volcanism. Its eruptions are characteristically moderate (VEI 1–3), involving explosive ash columns, ashfall, and occasional lava flows rather than the catastrophic Plinian eruptions seen at some other stratovolcanoes.

faqs.question: Can you hike Gamalama?
faqs.answer: Yes, the summit of Gamalama can be hiked when volcanic alert levels permit. The standard route starts from the village of Marikurubu or Tabala on the eastern flank and takes approximately 3–5 hours to ascend to the 1,714 m (5,623 ft) peak. The trail passes through clove plantations, tropical forest, and barren volcanic terrain to the crater rim, which offers panoramic views of the Molucca Sea, Halmahera, Tidore, and other volcanic islands. A local guide is strongly recommended. Summit access may be restricted during periods of elevated volcanic alert, so hikers should check current PVMBG alert levels. Ternate is accessible by domestic flights from Manado, Makassar, and Jakarta.

faqs.question: Why is Ternate historically important?
faqs.answer: Ternate, the island formed by Gamalama volcano, was the epicenter of the global spice trade for centuries. Cloves were native to the Moluccas (Spice Islands), and Ternate was the world's primary source. Portuguese traders arrived in 1512, followed by the Spanish and Dutch, who fought wars over control of this tiny volcanic island. The Sultanate of Ternate, one of the oldest Islamic sultanates in Southeast Asia (established ~1257), was a powerful regional kingdom. In 1858, the naturalist Alfred Russel Wallace wrote his famous paper on natural selection while staying on Ternate — a foundational moment in the history of evolutionary biology.

faqs.question: How dangerous is Gamalama?
faqs.answer: Gamalama poses a significant risk primarily due to population exposure rather than exceptional eruptive power. While its recorded eruptions have not exceeded VEI 3, approximately 220,000 people live on the volcano's flanks with no land-based evacuation route — the only escape is by sea. Hazards include ashfall (affecting the entire island even in moderate eruptions), ballistic projectiles near the summit, pyroclastic density currents, and lahars during heavy rainfall. The concentration of all critical infrastructure — airport, port, hospitals, government — on a single volcanic island creates a scenario where even a moderate eruption could have outsized humanitarian and logistical consequences.

faqs.question: What is the double subduction zone beneath Gamalama?
faqs.answer: Gamalama sits on the Halmahera volcanic arc, which is generated by one of the rarest tectonic configurations on Earth: a double subduction zone. The Molucca Sea Plate, a remnant oceanic plate trapped between the Philippine Sea Plate and the Eurasian Plate, is being subducted from both its western and eastern margins simultaneously — westward beneath the Sangihe arc and eastward beneath the Halmahera arc. This means the Molucca Sea Plate is essentially being consumed from both sides, a process that will eventually cause it to disappear entirely. This unusual tectonic setting generates the magma that feeds Gamalama and the other volcanoes of the Halmahera arc.
